title: Myer misled but no-one listened
text:
The case made by Elliott and his team, led by Norman O'Bryan, QC, was that Brookes, and by extension Myer, did not actually have reasonable grounds to provide the profit outlook it gave on September 11, 2014.

Even in the days after Brooks predicted a profit above $98.5 million, the consensus of analysts on Bloomberg was for a profit of just $92 million. Paul Jeffers

Furthermore, the applicant argued that Myer breached its continous disclosure obligations – and so misled or deceived the market – by failing to update guidance by no later than November 11, 2015, when it knew its profit wouldn’t hit the expected mark.

Beach backed this view, setting out no less than seven points between November 21, 2014, and February 27, 2015, where Myer should have updated guidance.

“By not having so corrected at each of these points in time, Myer engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct.”

Now that should have been great news for Elliott, who sat impassively though the short hearing on Thursday.

But Beach then dropped another bombshell: It’s not clear that anyone suffered any loss from Myer’s lack of disclosure, because the market didn’t actually believe Brookes’ forecast.

Even in the days after Brookes predicted a profit above $98.5 million, the consensus of analysts on Bloomberg was for a profit of just $92 million – and in the view of Beach, this bearish view was built into the Myer share price.

Advertisement

“The applicant and group members may not have suffered any loss flowing from the contraventions that I have identified,” Beach wrote.

“This is because the market price for Myer securities at the time the contraventions occurred already factored in an NPAT well south of Mr Brookes’ rosy picture painted on September 11, 2014.

“In other words, the hard-edged scepticism of market analysts and market makers at the time of the contraventions had already deflated Mr Brookes’ inflated views.”

That’s a bit of a blow for Bernie. But it’s also a blow for Elliott, who after 12 months of hard graft finds himself facing even more work.

While Beach wasn’t convinced the entire group of investors in the action suffered a loss, he has left the door open for individuals to make a case that they did suffer a loss.

Presumably, they will need to show they relied directly on Brookes’ representations on the profit outlook for 2014-15, and not market consensus.

This may well require Elliott writing to each of them individually and then finding a way for them to make their own claim. So Myer isn’t out of the woods yet.

But for those in the market closely watching this judgement, what does it all mean? Can boards and their advisers take Beach’s judgment to mean that if a company misleads and no-one listens, the damage is minimal?

Advertisement

Probably not.

At first blush, it seems Beach will force boards to reflect not only on the provision of guidance, but on how that guidance is interpreted by the market.

Beach is clear that Myer should have made it clear in late November 2014 that Brookes' outlook statement was off the mark.

But the subsequent updates that Beach says should have been provided to the market are instructive. In each case, he appears to indicate that Myer should have taken into account not just its formal forecast, but where market consensus sat.

As mentioned, consensus for Myer’s 2014-15 profit started at $92 million would subsequently fall to be at $89 million just before Myer dropped its profit downgrade bomb.

Beach suggests that after telling the market in November that its profit would have been below the prior year, Myer should have said at a number of key points profit was likely below $90 million – that is, around where guidance sat.

This would appear to provide precedent to support the idea that a company can mislead not just by failing to correct guidance promptly, but also by failing to ensure market consensus is reasonable.
description: The verdict of the first ever shareholder class action can best be summed up with that most Australian of phrases: Yeah, nah.
